speech.line: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: For God’s sake, lords, give signal to the fight.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: What say’st thou, Henry, wilt thou yield the crown?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Why, how now, long-tongu’d Warwick, dare you speak?
When you and I met at Saint Albons last,
Your legs did better service than your hands.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Then ’twas my turn to fly, and now ’tis thine.

speech.speaker: CLIF.
speech.line: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: ’Twas not your valor, Clifford, drove me thence.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently.
Break off the parley, for scarce I can refrain
The execution of my big-swoll’n heart
Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.

speech.speaker: CLIF.
speech.line: I slew thy father, call’st thou him a child?

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward,
As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland,
But ere sunset I’ll make thee curse the deed.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: I prithee give no limits to my tongue,
I am a king, and privileg’d to speak.

speech.speaker: CLIF.
speech.line: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here
Cannot be cur’d by words; therefore be still.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword.
By Him that made us all, I am resolv’d
That Clifford’s manhood lies upon his tongue.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no?
A thousand men have broke their fasts today
That ne’er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head,
For York in justice puts his armor on.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: If that be right which Warwick says is right,
There is no wrong, but every thing is right.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands,
For well I wot, thou hast thy mother’s tongue.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam,
But like a foul misshapen stigmatic,
Mark’d by the destinies to be avoided,
As venom toads, or lizards’ dreadful stings.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Iron of Naples hid with English gilt,
Whose father bears the title of a king
(As if a channel should be call’d the sea),
Sham’st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,
To let thy tongue detect thy base-born heart?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns
To make this shameless callet know herself.
Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou,
Although thy husband may be Menelaus;
And ne’er was Agamemnon’s brother wrong’d
By that false woman as this king by thee.
His father revell’d in the heart of France,
And tam’d the King and made the Dauphin stoop;
And had he match’d according to his state,
He might have kept that glory to this day.
But when he took a beggar to his bed,
And grac’d thy poor sire with his bridal day,
Even then that sunshine brew’d a show’r for him,
That wash’d his father’s fortunes forth of France,
And heap’d sedition on his crown at home.
For what hath broach’d this tumult but thy pride?
Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept,
And we, in pity of the gentle king,
Had slipp’d our claim until another age.

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring,
And that thy summer bred us no increase,
We set the axe to thy usurping root;
And though the edge hath something hit ourselves,
Yet know thou, since we have begun to strike,
We’ll never leave till we have hewn thee down,
Or bath’d thy growing with our heated bloods.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: And in this resolution, I defy thee,
Not willing any longer conference,
Since thou deniedst the gentle king to speak.
Sound trumpets! Let our bloody colors wave!
And either victory, or else a grave.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Stay, Edward.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: No, wrangling woman, we’ll no longer stay,
These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. A battlefield between Towton and Saxton.
scene.scenepersonae: (Warwick, Edward, George of Clarence, Richard)
scene.scenedescription: The exhausted Warwick is joined by Edward and George, who think the battle lost. Richard comes running in with the news of the death of Warwick’s brother, which rouses him and brings him back to the fight. The men leave to rally their troops and counterattack.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Forespent with toil, as runners with a race,
I lay me down a little while to breathe;
For strokes receiv’d and many blows repaid
Have robb’d my strong-knit sinews of their strength,
And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Smile, gentle heaven! Or strike, ungentle death!
For this world frowns, and Edward’s sun is clouded.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: How now, my lord, what hap? What hope of good?

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair,
Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us.
What counsel give you? Whither shall we fly?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings,
And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?
Thy brother’s blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
Broach’d with the steely point of Clifford’s lance;
And in the very pangs of death he cried,
Like to a dismal clangor heard from far,
“Warwick, revenge! Brother, revenge my death!”
So underneath the belly of their steeds,
That stain’d their fetlocks in his smoking blood,
The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood!
I’ll kill my horse, because I will not fly.
Why stand we like soft-hearted women here,
Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage,
And look upon, as if the tragedy
Were play’d in jest by counterfeiting actors?
Here on my knee I vow to God above
I’ll never pause again, never stand still,
Till either death hath clos’d these eyes of mine
Or fortune given me measure of revenge.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine,
And in this vow do chain my soul to thine!
And ere my knee rise from the earth’s cold face,
I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to Thee,
Thou setter-up and plucker-down of kings,
Beseeching thee (if with thy will it stands)
That to my foes this body must be prey,
Yet that thy brazen gates of heaven may ope
And give sweet passage to my sinful soul!
Now, lords, take leave until we meet again,
Where e’er it be, in heaven or in earth.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Brother, give me thy hand, and gentle Warwick,
Let me embrace thee in my weary arms.
I, that did never weep, now melt with woe
That winter should cut off our spring-time so.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords, farewell.

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: Yet let us all together to our troops,
And give them leave to fly that will not stay;
And call them pillars that will stand to us;
And if we thrive, promise them such rewards
As victors wear at the Olympian games.
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts,
For yet is hope of life and victory.
Foreslow no longer, make we hence amain.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the battlefield between Towton and Saxton.
scene.scenepersonae: (Richard, Clifford, Warwick)
scene.scenedescription: Richard meets Clifford and fights him. Warwick enters and Clifford flees. Richard insists that Clifford is his to kill.
scene.stagedir: Excursions. Enter Richard at one door and Clifford at the other.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone:
Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York,
And this for Rutland, both bound to revenge,
Wert thou environ’d with a brazen wall.

speech.speaker: CLIF.
speech.line: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone:
This is the hand that stabb’d thy father York,
And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland,
And here’s the heart that triumphs in their death,
And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother
To execute the like upon thyself—
And so have at thee!

scene.stagedir: Alarums. They fight. Warwick comes; Clifford flies.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Nay, Warwick, single out some other chase,
For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the battlefield between Towton and Saxton.
scene.scenepersonae: (King Henry, A Son That Has Killed His Father, A Father That Has Killed His Son, Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, Exeter)
scene.scenedescription: King Henry, dismissed as useless by the Queen and Clifford, wanders about wishing he was not King, but merely a shepherd. A soldier comes in to despoil the corpse of an enemy he killed, who turns out to be his own father; and another, planning to do the same, discovers that he has killed his own son. The horrified King’s heart breaks as he considers how many more such cases there must be, wishing he could die and stop it all. Margaret rushes in to tell him to flee, as the royalist forces have lost the day; docilely, he lets himself be led.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: This battle fares like to the morning’s war,
When dying clouds contend with growing light,
What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,
Can neither call it perfect day nor night.
Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea
Forc’d by the tide to combat with the wind;
Now sways it that way, like the self-same sea
Forc’d to retire by fury of the wind.
Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;
Now one the better, then another best;
Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,
Yet neither conqueror nor conquered;
So is the equal poise of this fell war.
Here on this molehill will I sit me down.
To whom God will, there be the victory!
For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too,
Have chid me from the battle; swearing both
They prosper best of all when I am thence.
Would I were dead, if God’s good will were so;
For what is in this world but grief and woe?
O God! Methinks it were a happy life
To be no better than a homely swain,
To sit upon a hill, as I do now,
To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,
Thereby to see the minutes how they run:
How many makes the hour full complete,
How many hours brings about the day,
How many days will finish up the year,
How many years a mortal man may live.
When this is known, then to divide the times:
So many hours must I tend my flock,
So many hours must I take my rest,
So many hours must I contemplate,
So many hours must I sport myself,
So many days my ewes have been with young,
So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean,
So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:
So minutes, hours, days, months, and years,
Pass’d over to the end they were created,
Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.
Ah! What a life were this! How sweet! How lovely!
Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade
To shepherds looking on their silly sheep
Than doth a rich embroider’d canopy
To kings that fear their subjects’ treachery?
O yes, it doth; a thousandfold it doth.
And to conclude, the shepherd’s homely curds,
His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle,
His wonted sleep under a fresh tree’s shade,
All which secure and sweetly he enjoys,
Is far beyond a prince’s delicates—
His viands sparkling in a golden cup,
His body couched in a curious bed,
When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter A Son That Has Killed His Father, at one door, dragging in the dead body.

speech.speaker: SON.
speech.line: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.
This man whom hand to hand I slew in fight
May be possessed with some store of crowns,
And I that, haply, take them from him now,
May yet, ere night, yield both my life and them
To some man else, as this dead man doth me.
Who’s this? O God! It is my father’s face,
Whom in this conflict I, unwares, have kill’d.
O heavy times, begetting such events!
From London by the King was I press’d forth;
My father, being the Earl of Warwick’s man,
Came on the part of York, press’d by his master;
And I, who at his hands receiv’d my life,
Have by my hands of life bereaved him.
Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!
And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;
And no more words till they have flow’d their fill.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!
Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,
Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.
Weep, wretched man; I’ll aid thee tear for tear,
And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war,
Be blind with tears, and break o’ercharg’d with grief.

scene.stagedir: Enter A Father That Has Killed His Son, at another door, bearing of his son.

speech.speaker: FATH.
speech.line: Thou that so stoutly hath resisted me,
Give me thy gold—if thou hast any gold—
For I have bought it with an hundred blows.
But let me see: is this our foeman’s face?
Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!
Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee,
Throw up thine eye! See, see what show’rs arise,
Blown with the windy tempest of my heart
Upon thy wounds, that kills mine eye and heart!
O, pity, God, this miserable age!
What stratagems! How fell! How butcherly!
Erroneous, mutinous, and unnatural,
This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!
O boy! Thy father gave thee life too soon,
And hath bereft thee of thy life too late.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Woe above woe! Grief more than common grief!
O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!
O, pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!
The red rose and the white are on his face,
The fatal colors of our striving houses;
The one his purple blood right well resembles,
The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth.
Wither one rose, and let the other flourish;
If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.

speech.speaker: SON.
speech.line: How will my mother for a father’s death
Take on with me, and ne’er be satisfied!

speech.speaker: FATH.
speech.line: How will my wife for slaughter of my son
Shed seas of tears, and ne’er be satisfied!

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: How will the country for these woeful chances
Misthink the King, and not be satisfied!

speech.speaker: SON.
speech.line: Was ever son so ru’d a father’s death?

speech.speaker: FATH.
speech.line: Was ever father so bemoan’d his son?

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Was ever king so griev’d for subjects’ woe?
Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.

speech.speaker: SON.
speech.line: I’ll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

speech.speaker: FATH.
speech.line: These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet;
My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre,
For from my heart thine image ne’er shall go;
My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;
And so obsequious will thy father be,
E’en for the loss of thee, having no more,
As Priam was for all his valiant sons.
I’ll bear thee hence, and let them fight that will,
For I have murdered where I should not kill.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care,
Here sits a king more woeful than you are.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Excursions. Enter the Queen Margaret, the Prince Edward, and Exeter.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Fly, father, fly! For all your friends are fled,
And Warwick rages like a chafed bull.
Away! For death doth hold us in pursuit.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Mount you, my lord, towards Berwick post amain.
Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds
Having the fearful flying hare in sight,
With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath,
And bloody steel grasp’d in their ireful hands,
Are at our backs, and therefore hence amain.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Away! For vengeance comes along with them.
Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed,
Or else come after. I’ll away before.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter;
Not that I fear to stay, but love to go
Whither the Queen intends. Forward, away!

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the battlefield between Towton and Saxton.
scene.scenepersonae: (Clifford, Edward, Warwick, Richard, Soldiers, Montague, George of Clarence)
scene.scenedescription: Clifford, shot through the neck with an arrow, realizes he is about to die. He bemoans the failure of Henry’s cause and faints. Edward, George, Richard and Warwick enter victorious, and finding Clifford’s body mock it soundly, not realizing that he is now dead. Warwick orders that the head be cut off. He then explains his plans: to have Edward crowned, and then to enlist French support for their cause by marrying him to the French King’s sister, Lady Bona. Edward agrees, and names his brothers Dukes of Clarence and Gloucester respectively.
scene.stagedir: A loud alarum. Enter Clifford wounded with an arrow in his neck.

speech.speaker: CLIF.
speech.line: Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies,
Which whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light.
O Lancaster! I fear thy overthrow
More than my body’s parting with my soul.
My love and fear glu’d many friends to thee,
And now I fall, thy tough commixtures melts,
Impairing Henry, strength’ning misproud York.
The common people swarm like summer flies,
And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?
And who shines now but Henry’s enemies?
O Phoebus! Hadst thou never given consent
That Phaëton should check thy fiery steeds,
Thy burning car never had scorch’d the earth.
And, Henry, hadst thou sway’d as kings should do,
Or as thy father and his father did,
Giving no ground unto the house of York,
They never then had sprung like summer flies;
I and ten thousand in this luckless realm
Had left no mourning widows for our death,
And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?
Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds;
No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight.
The foe is merciless, and will not pity;
For at their hands I have deserv’d no pity.
The air hath got into my deadly wounds,
And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.
Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest,
I stabb’d your fathers’ bosoms, split my breast.

scene.stagedir: Alarum and retreat. Enter Edward, Warwick, Richard, and Soldiers, Montague, and George of Clarence.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Now breathe we, lords, good fortune bids us pause
And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.
Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen,
That led calm Henry, though he were a king,
As doth a sail, fill’d with a fretting gust,
Command an argosy to stem the waves.
But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: No, ’tis impossible he should escape;
For (though before his face I speak the words)
Your brother Richard mark’d him for the grave,
And wheresoe’er he is, he’s surely dead.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?
A deadly groan, like life and death’s departing.
See who it is.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: And, now the battle’s ended,
If friend or foe, let him be gently used.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Revoke that doom of mercy, for ’tis Clifford,
Who, not contented that he lopp’d the branch
In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth,
But set his murd’ring knife unto the root
From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,
I mean our princely father, Duke of York.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: From off the gates of York fetch down the head,
Your father’s head, which Clifford placed there;
In stead whereof let this supply the room:
Measure for measure must be answered.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Bring forth that fatal screech owl to our house
That nothing sung but death to us and ours.
Now death shall stop his dismal threat’ning sound,
And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: I think his understanding is bereft.
Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?
Dark cloudy death o’ershades his beams of life,
And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: O would he did! And so, perhaps, he doth;
’Tis but his policy to counterfeit,
Because he would avoid such bitter taunts
Which in the time of death he gave our father.

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: If so thou think’st, vex him with eager words.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Thou pitiedst Rutland, I will pity thee.

speech.speaker: GEO.
speech.line: Where’s Captain Margaret, to fence you now?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: They mock thee, Clifford, swear as thou wast wont.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: What, not an oath? Nay, then the world goes hard
When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.
I know by that he’s dead, and by my soul,
If this right hand would buy two hours’ life
That I, in all despite, might rail at him,
This hand should chop it off; and with the issuing blood
Stifle the villain whose unstanched thirst
York and young Rutland could not satisfy.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Ay, but he’s dead. Off with the traitor’s head,
And rear it in the place your father’s stands.
And now to London with triumphant march,
There to be crowned England’s royal king;
From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France,
And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen.
So shalt thou sinow both these lands together,
And having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread
The scatt’red foe that hopes to rise again;
For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,
Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.
First will I see the coronation,
And then to Brittany I’ll cross the sea
To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be;
For in thy shoulder do I build my seat,
And never will I undertake the thing
Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.
Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,
And George, of Clarence. Warwick, as ourself,
Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester,
For Gloucester’s dukedom is too ominous.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Tut, that’s a foolish observation.
Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London
To see these honors in possession.

scene.scenelocation: A forest in the North of England.
scene.scenepersonae: (First Gamekeeper, Second Gamekeeper, King Henry)
scene.scenedescription: Two gamekeepers lie in wait for deer, but find Henry instead; he discusses to himself how Margaret has gone to seek help in France, but how low the chances of success are. The two gamekeepers arrest him. He rebukes them mildly for breaking their oath to him, but they point how that they were only his subjects while he was king. He then goes with them, to be sent on to London.
scene.stagedir: Enter two Gamekeepers with cross-bows in their hands.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: Under this thick-grown brake we’ll shroud ourselves,
For through this laund anon the deer will come,
And in this covert will we make our stand,
Culling the principal of all the deer.

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: I’ll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: That cannot be, the noise of thy crossbow
Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.
Here stand we both and aim we at the best;
And for the time shall not seem tedious,
I’ll tell thee what befell me on a day
In this self place where now we mean to stand.

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Here comes a man, let’s stay till he be past.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King Henry, disguised, with a prayer-book.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: From Scotland am I stol’n, even of pure love,
To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.
No, Harry, Harry, ’tis no land of thine;
Thy place is fill’d, thy sceptre wrung from thee,
Thy balm wash’d off wherewith thou was anointed.
No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,
No humble suitors press to speak for right,
No, not a man comes for redress of thee;
For how can I help them and not myself?

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: Ay, here’s a deer whose skin’s a keeper’s fee:
This is the quondam king; let’s seize upon him.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Let me embrace thee, sour adversities,
For wise men say it is the wisest course.

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Why linger we? Let us lay hands upon him.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: Forbear awhile, we’ll hear a little more.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: My queen and son are gone to France for aid;
And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick
Is thither gone to crave the French king’s sister
To wife for Edward. If this news be true,
Poor queen and son, your labor is but lost;
For Warwick is a subtle orator,
And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words.
By this account then, Margaret may win him,
For she’s a woman to be pitied much.
Her sighs will make a batt’ry in his breast,
Her tears will pierce into a marble heart;
The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn;
And Nero will be tainted with remorse
To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears.
Ay, but she’s come to beg; Warwick, to give:
She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry;
He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward.
She weeps, and says her Henry is depos’d;
He smiles, and says his Edward is install’d;
That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more;
Whiles Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong,
Inferreth arguments of mighty strength,
And in conclusion wins the King from her
With promise of his sister and what else,
To strengthen and support King Edward’s place.
O Margaret, thus ’twill be, and thou, poor soul,
Art then forsaken, as thou went’st forlorn!

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Say, what art thou talk’st of kings and queens?

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: More than I seem, and less than I was born to;
A man at least, for less I should not be;
And men may talk of kings, and why not I?

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Ay, but thou talk’st as if thou wert a king.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Why, so I am—in mind, and that’s enough.

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: But if thou be a king, where is thy crown?

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: My crown is in my heart, not on my head;
Not deck’d with diamonds and Indian stones,
Nor to be seen. My crown is call’d content,
A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Well, if you be a king crown’d with content,
Your crown content and you must be contented
To go along with us; for, as we think,
You are the king King Edward hath depos’d;
And we his subjects, sworn in all allegiance,
Will apprehend you as his enemy.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: But did you never swear and break an oath?

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: No, never such an oath, nor will not now.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?

speech.speaker: 2. KEEP.
speech.line: Here in this country where we now remain.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: I was anointed king at nine months old,
My father and my grandfather were kings;
And you were sworn true subjects unto me;
And tell me then, have you not broke your oaths?

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: No,
For we were subjects but while you were king.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Why? Am I dead? Do I not breathe a man?
Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear!
Look, as I blow this feather from my face,
And as the air blows it to me again,
Obeying with my wind when I do blow,
And yielding to another when it blows,
Commanded always by the greater gust,
Such is the lightness of you common men.
But do not break your oaths, for of that sin
My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.
Go where you will, the King shall be commanded;
And be you kings: command, and I’ll obey.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: We are true subjects to the King, King Edward.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: So would you be again to Henry,
If he were seated as King Edward is.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEP.
speech.line: We charge you, in God’s name and the King’s,
To go with us unto the officers.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: In God’s name lead; your king’s name be obey’d,
And what God will, that let your king perform;
And what he will, I humbly yield unto.

scene.scenelocation: London. A palace room.
scene.scenepersonae: (King Edward, Gloucester, Clarence, Lady Grey, Nobleman)
scene.scenedescription: Lady Grey asks Edward to return her husband’s lands to her, since he died fighting in the Yorkist cause. Edward is taken with the lady, and quite crudely solicits her, agreeing to hand the lands back if she’ll sleep with him. Gloucester and Clarence observe amusedly until she indignantly refuses and Edward offers to marry her instead. Left alone, the deformed Richard considers how his shape leaves him no joy in life, and decides to seek the crown, though he is as yet uncertain how to go about it.
scene.stagedir: Enter King Edward, Gloucester, Clarence, Lady Grey.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Albons field
This lady’s husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain,
His land then seiz’d on by the conqueror.
Her suit is now to repossess those lands,
Which we in justice cannot well deny,
Because in quarrel of the house of York
The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Your Highness shall do well to grant her suit;
It were dishonor to deny it her.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: It were no less, but yet I’ll make a pause.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Yea, is it so?
I see the lady hath a thing to grant,
Before the King will grant her humble suit.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: He knows the game; how true he keeps the wind!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Silence!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Widow, we will consider of your suit,
And come some other time to know our mind.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay.
May it please your Highness to resolve me now,
And what your pleasure is shall satisfy me.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, widow? Then I’ll warrant you all your lands,
And if what pleases him shall pleasure you.
Fight closer or, good faith, You’ll catch a blow.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I fear her not, unless she chance to fall.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: God forbid that, for he’ll take vantages.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: How many children hast thou, widow? Tell me.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I think he means to beg a child of her.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Nay then whip me; he’ll rather give her two.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Three, my most gracious lord.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: You shall have four and You’ll be rul’d by him.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: ’Twere pity they should lose their father’s lands.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Lords, give us leave. I’ll try this widow’s wit.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, good leave have you, for you will have leave
Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: And would you not do much to do them good?

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: To do them good I would sustain some harm.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Then get your husband’s lands, to do them good.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Therefore I came unto your Majesty.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: I’ll tell you how these lands are to be got.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: So shall you bind me to your Highness’ service.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: What service wilt thou do me if I give them?

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: What you command that rests in me to do.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Why then I will do what your Grace commands.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He plies her hard, and much rain wears the marble.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: As red as fire? Nay then, her wax must melt.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Why stops my lord? Shall I not hear my task?

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: An easy task, ’tis but to love a king.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: That’s soon perform’d, because I am a subject.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Why then, thy husband’s lands I freely give thee.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The match is made, she seals it with a cur’sy.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: But stay thee, ’tis the fruits of love I mean.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Ay, but I fear me in another sense.
What love, think’st thou, I sue so much to get?

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers—
That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Why then you mean not as I thought you did.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: My mind will never grant what I perceive
Your Highness aims at, if I aim aright.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Why then thou shalt not have thy husband’s lands.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Why then mine honesty shall be my dower,
For by that loss I will not purchase them.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Therein thou wrong’st thy children mightily.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Herein your Highness wrongs both them and me.
But, mighty lord, this merry inclination
Accords not with the sadness of my suit.
Please you dismiss me, either with ay or no.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Ay, if thou wilt say ay to my request;
No, if thou dost say no to my demand.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: Then no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The widow likes him not, she knits her brows.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: He is the bluntest wooer in Christendom.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Her looks doth argue her replete with modesty,
Her words doth show her wit incomparable,
All her perfections challenge sovereignty:
One way or other, she is for a king,
And she shall be my love or else my queen.—
Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: ’Tis better said than done, my gracious lord.
I am a subject fit to jest withal,
But far unfit to be a sovereign.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee
I speak no more than what my soul intends,
And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: And that is more than I will yield unto.
I know I am too mean to be your queen,
And yet too good to be your concubine.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: You cavil, widow, I did mean my queen.

speech.speaker: L. GREY.
speech.line: ’Twill grieve your Grace my sons should call you father.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: No more than when my daughters call thee mother.
Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children,
And by God’s Mother, I, being but a bachelor,
Have other some. Why, ’tis a happy thing
To be the father unto many sons.
Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The ghostly father now hath done his shrift.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: When he was made a shriver, ’twas for shift.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: You’ld think it strange if I should marry her.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: To who, my lord?

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Why, Clarence, to myself.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: That would be ten days’ wonder at the least.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: That’s a day longer than a wonder lasts.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Well, jest on, brothers. I can tell you both
Her suit is granted for her husband’s lands.

speech.speaker: NOB.
speech.line: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken,
And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: See that he be convey’d unto the Tower;
And go we, brothers, to the man that took him,
To question of his apprehension.
Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honorably.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, Edward will use women honorably.
Would he were wasted, marrow, bones, and all,
That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring,
To cross me from the golden time I look for!
And yet, between my soul’s desire and me—
The lustful Edward’s title buried—
Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward,
And all the unlook’d-for issue of their bodies
To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:
A cold premeditation for my purpose!
Why then I do but dream on sovereignty,
Like one that stands upon a promontory
And spies a far-off shore where he would tread,
Wishing his foot were equal with his eye,
And chides the sea that sunders him from thence,
Saying, he’ll lade it dry to have his way:
So do I wish the crown, being so far off,
And so I chide the means that keeps me from it,
And so, I say, I’ll cut the causes off,
Flattering me with impossibilities.
My eye’s too quick, my heart o’erweens too much,
Unless my hand and strength could equal them.
Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard;
What other pleasure can the world afford?
I’ll make my heaven in a lady’s lap,
And deck my body in gay ornaments,
And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.
O miserable thought! And more unlikely
Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!
Why, love forswore me in my mother’s womb;
And for I should not deal in her soft laws,
She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe,
To shrink mine arm up like a wither’d shrub,
To make an envious mountain on my back,
Where sits deformity to mock my body;
To shape my legs of an unequal size,
To disproportion me in every part,
Like to a chaos, or an unlick’d bear-whelp
That carries no impression like the dam.
And am I then a man to be belov’d?
O monstrous fault, to harbor such a thought!
Then since this earth affords no joy to me
But to command, to check, to o’erbear such
As are of better person than myself,
I’ll make my heaven to dream upon the crown,
And whiles I live, t’ account this world but hell,
Until my misshap’d trunk that bears this head
Be round impaled with a glorious crown.
And yet I know not how to get the crown,
For many lives stand between me and home;
And I—like one lost in a thorny wood,
That rents the thorns, and is rent with the thorns,
Seeking a way, and straying from the way,
Not knowing how to find the open air,
But toiling desperately to find it out—
Torment myself to catch the English crown;
And from that torment I will free myself,
Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,
And cry “Content” to that which grieves my heart,
And wet my cheeks with artificial tears,
And frame my face to all occasions.
I’ll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall,
I’ll slay more gazers than the basilisk,
I’ll play the orator as well as Nestor,
Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,
And like a Sinon, take another Troy.
I can add colors to the chameleon,
Change shapes with Proteus for advantages,
And set the murderous Machevil to school.
Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?
Tut, were it farther off, I’ll pluck it down.

scene.scenelocation: France. A room in King Lewis XI’s palace.
scene.scenepersonae: (Lewis the French King, Lady Bona, Admiral Bourbon, Prince Edward, Queen Margaret, Earl of Oxford, Warwick, Post)
scene.scenedescription: Margaret begs for help from King Lewis of France, who seems well-disposed towards her until Warwick arrives with the offer that Edward should marry Lewis’s sister Bona. Margaret tries to wreck the diplomacy, but when Lewis questions Warwick further and decides that Edward is well-settled as King, her efforts come to naught. All is arranged between Warwick and Lewis, until a messenger arrives with letters informing Warwick that Edward has married Lady Grey. Infuriated at being publically made a fool like this, Warwick immediately abandons Edward’s cause and rallies to Margaret. With the French, they plan an invasion to overthrow the Yorkist regime. Warwick and Margaret agree to marry their children to each other.
scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Lewis the French King, his sister Lady Bona, his Admiral, call’d Bourbon, Prince Edward, Queen Margaret, and the Earl of Oxford. Lewis sits, and riseth up again.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret,
Sit down with us. It ill befits thy state
And birth that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: No, mighty King of France; now Margaret
Must strike her sail and learn a while to serve
Where kings command. I was, I must confess,
Great Albion’s queen in former golden days;
But now mischance hath trod my title down,
And with dishonor laid me on the ground,
Where I must take like seat unto my fortune,
And to my humble seat conform myself.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
And stops my tongue, while heart is drown’d in cares.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: What e’er it be, be thou still like thyself,
And sit thee by our side.
Yield not thy neck
To fortune’s yoke, but let thy dauntless mind
Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;
It shall be eas’d if France can yield relief.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.
Now therefore be it known to noble Lewis,
That Henry, sole possessor of my love,
Is, of a king, become a banish’d man,
And forc’d to live in Scotland a forlorn;
While proud ambitious Edward, Duke of York,
Usurps the regal title and the seat
Of England’s true-anointed lawful king.
This is the cause that I, poor Margaret,
With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry’s heir,
Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid;
And if thou fail us, all our hope is done.
Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our treasure seiz’d, our soldiers put to flight,
And as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm,
While we bethink a means to break it off.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: The more I stay, the more I’ll succor thee.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow.
And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: What’s he approacheth boldly to our presence?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward’s greatest friend.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise,
For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
My lord and sovereign and thy vowed friend,
I come, in kindness and unfeigned love,
First, to do greetings to thy royal person,
And then to crave a league of amity,
And lastly, to confirm that amity
With nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant
That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister,
To England’s king in lawful marriage.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: If that go forward, Henry’s hope is done.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: And, gracious madam
in our king’s behalf
I am commanded, with your leave and favor,
Humbly to kiss your hand, and with my tongue
To tell the passion of my sovereign’s heart,
Where fame, late ent’ring at his heedful ears,
Hath plac’d thy beauty’s image and thy virtue.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak
Before you answer Warwick. His demand
Springs not from Edward’s well-meant honest love,
But from deceit bred by necessity;
For how can tyrants safely govern home,
Unless abroad they purchase great alliance?
To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice,
That Henry liveth still; but were he dead,
Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry’s son.
Look therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage
Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonor;
For though usurpers sway the rule a while,
Yet heav’ns are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Injurious Margaret!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And why not Queen?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Because thy father Henry did usurp,
And thou no more art prince than she is queen.

speech.speaker: OXF.
speech.line: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt,
Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain;
And after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;
And after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth,
Who by his prowess conquered all France:
From these our Henry lineally descends.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Oxford, how haps it in this smooth discourse
You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost
All that which Henry the Fifth had gotten?
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
But for the rest: you tell a pedigree
Of threescore and two years—a silly time
To make prescription for a kingdom’s worth.

speech.speaker: OXF.
speech.line: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege,
Whom thou obey’dst thirty and six years,
And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right,
Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?
For shame, leave Henry, and call Edward king.

speech.speaker: OXF.
speech.line: Call him my king by whose injurious doom
My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere,
Was done to death? And more than so, my father,
Even in the downfall of his mellow’d years,
When nature brought him to the door of death?
No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm,
This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: And I the house of York.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside,
While I use further conference with Warwick.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Heavens grant that Warwick’s words bewitch him not!

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Now, Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience,
Is Edward your true king? For I were loath
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honor.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: But is he gracious in the people’s eye?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Then further: all dissembling set aside,
Tell me for truth the measure of his love
Unto our sister Bona.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Such it seems
As may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have often heard him say, and swear,
That this his love was an eternal plant,
Whereof the root was fix’d in virtue’s ground,
The leaves and fruit maintain’d with beauty’s sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,
Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

speech.speaker: BONA.
speech.line: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine.
Yet I confess that often ere this day,
When I have heard your king’s desert recounted,
Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward’s.
And now forthwith shall articles be drawn
Touching the jointure that your king must make,
Which with her dowry shall be counterpois’d.
Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness
That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: To Edward, but not to the English king.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Deceitful Warwick, it was thy device
By this alliance to make void my suit.
Before thy coming, Lewis was Henry’s friend.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: And still is friend to him and Margaret.
But if your title to the crown be weak,
As may appear by Edward’s good success,
Then ’tis but reason that I be releas’d
From giving aid which late I promised.
Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
That your estate requires and mine can yield.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease;
Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.
And as for you yourself, our quondam queen,
You have a father able to maintain you,
And better ’twere you troubled him than France.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick,
Proud setter-up and puller-down of kings!
I will not hence, till with my talk and tears
(Both full of truth) I make King Lewis behold
Thy sly conveyance and thy lord’s false love,
For both of you are birds of self-same feather.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: My lord ambassador, these letters are for you,
Sent from your brother, Marquess Montague.
These from our king unto your Majesty.
And, madam, these for you; from whom I know not.

speech.speaker: OXF.
speech.line: I like it well that our fair queen and mistress
Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps as he were nettled.
I hope all’s for the best.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Warwick, what are thy news? And yours, fair queen?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Mine such as fill my heart with unhop’d joys.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Mine full of sorrow and heart’s discontent.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: What? Has your king married the Lady Grey?
And now to soothe your forgery and his,
Sends me a paper to persuade me patience?
Is this th’ alliance that he seeks with France?
Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: I told your Majesty as much before:
This proveth Edward’s love and Warwick’s honesty.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: King Lewis, I here protest in sight of heaven,
And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss,
That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward’s;
No more my king, for he dishonors me,
But most himself if he could see his shame.
Did I forget that by the house of York
My father came untimely to his death?
Did I let pass th’ abuse done to my niece?
Did I impale him with the regal crown?
Did I put Henry from his native right?
And am I guerdon’d at the last with shame?
Shame on himself! For my desert is honor;
And to repair my honor lost for him,
I here renounce him and return to Henry.
My noble queen, let former grudges pass,
And henceforth I am thy true servitor.
I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his former state.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Warwick, these words have turn’d my hate to love,
And I forgive and quite forget old faults,
And joy that thou becom’st King Henry’s friend.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend,
That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us
With some few bands of chosen soldiers,
I’ll undertake to land them on our coast,
And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
’Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him,
And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me,
He’s very likely now to fall from him,
For matching more for wanton lust than honor,
Or than for strength and safety of our country.

speech.speaker: BONA.
speech.line: Dear brother, how shall Bona be reveng’d
But by thy help to this distressed queen?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live,
Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

speech.speaker: BONA.
speech.line: My quarrel and this English queen’s are one.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: And mine, fair Lady Bona, joins with yours.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret’s.
Therefore, at last, I firmly am resolv’d
You shall have aid.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Then, England’s messenger, return in post,
And tell false Edward, thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride.
Thou seest what’s pass’d, go fear thy king withal.

speech.speaker: BONA.
speech.line: Tell him, in hope he’ll prove a widower shortly,
I wear the willow garland for his sake.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside,
And I am ready to put armor on.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I’ll uncrown him ere’t be long.
There’s thy reward, be gone.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: But, Warwick,
Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,
Shall cross the seas and bid false Edward battle;
And as occasion serves, this noble queen
And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
Yet ere thou go, but answer me one doubt:
What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: This shall assure my constant loyalty,
That if our queen and this young prince agree,
I’ll join mine eldest daughter, and my joy,
To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.
Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous,
Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick,
And with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable
That only Warwick’s daughter shall be thine.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it,
And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

scene.stagedir: He gives his hand to Warwick.

speech.speaker: K. LEW.
speech.line: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied,
And thou, Lord Bourbon, our High Admiral,
Shall waft them over with our royal fleet.
I long till Edward fall by war’s mischance,
For mocking marriage with a dame of France.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: I came from Edward as ambassador,
But I return his sworn and mortal foe.
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,
But dreadful war shall answer his demand.
Had he none else to make a stale but me?
Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.
I was the chief that rais’d him to the crown,
And I’ll be chief to bring him down again;
Not that I pity Henry’s misery,
But seek revenge on Edward’s mockery.

scene.scenelocation: London. A palace room.
scene.scenepersonae: (Richard of Gloucester, Clarence, Somerset, Montague, King Edward, Queen Elizabeth, Pembroke, Stafford, Hastings, Post)
scene.scenedescription: None of Edward’s noblemen, nor his brothers, are pleased with his choice of bride, especially as it has made an enemy of Warwick and Lewis of France, as well as because Edward is showering gifts on her relatives. They band together and tell him so. Edward airily dismisses their concerns, just as he refuses to be at all scared by the news of the alliance between Margaret, Lewis and Warwick. He begins to realize that his situation is precarious when both Somerset and his own brother Clarence abandon him for Warwick’s cause. Still, he remains confident.
scene.stagedir: Enter Richard of Gloucester, Clarence, Somerset, and Montague.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you
Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?
Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Alas, you know, ’tis far from hence to France;
How could he stay till Warwick made return?

speech.speaker: D. SOM.
speech.line: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the King.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King Edward, Lady Grey, now Queen Elizabeth, Pembroke, Stafford, Hastings, and others. Four stand on one side and four on the other.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: And his well-chosen bride.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice,
That you stand pensive as half malecontent?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: As well as Lewis of France or the Earl of Warwick,
Which are so weak of courage and in judgment
That they’ll take no offense at our abuse.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Suppose they take offense without a cause;
They are but Lewis and Warwick, I am Edward,
Your king and Warwick’s, and must have my will.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: And shall have your will, because our king.
Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Not I.
No; God forbid that I should wish them sever’d
Whom God hath join’d together; ay, and ’twere pity
To sunder them that yoke so well together.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside,
Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey
Should not become my wife and England’s queen.
And you too, Somerset and Montague,
Speak freely what you think.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis
Becomes your enemy, for mocking him
About the marriage of the Lady Bona.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge,
Is now dishonored by this new marriage.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeas’d
By such invention as I can devise?

speech.speaker: MONT.
speech.line: Yet, to have join’d with France in such alliance
Would more have strength’ned this our commonwealth
’Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Why, knows not Montague that of itself
England is safe, if true within itself?

speech.speaker: MONT.
speech.line: But the safer when ’tis back’d with France.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: ’Tis better using France than trusting France.
Let us be back’d with God, and with the seas,
Which he hath giv’n for fence impregnable,
And with their helps only defend ourselves:
In them, and in ourselves, our safety lies.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Ay, what of that? It was my will and grant,
And for this once my will shall stand for law.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: And yet methinks your Grace hath not done well
To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales
Unto the brother of your loving bride.
She better would have fitted me or Clarence;
But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Or else you would not have bestow’d the heir
Of the Lord Bonville on your new wive’s son,
And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Alas, poor Clarence! Is it for a wife
That thou art malecontent? I will provide thee.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: In choosing for yourself, you show’d your judgment;
Which being shallow, you shall give me leave
To play the broker in mine own behalf;
And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king,
And not be tied unto his brother’s will.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: My lords, before it pleas’d his Majesty
To raise my state to title of a queen,
Do me but right, and you must all confess
That I was not ignoble of descent,
And meaner than myself have had like fortune.
But as this title honors me and mine,
So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing,
Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns.
What danger or what sorrow can befall thee
So long as Edward is thy constant friend
And their true sovereign whom they must obey?
Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too,
Unless they seek for hatred at my hands;
Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe,
And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I hear, yet say not much, but think the more.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Now, messenger, what letters or what news
From France?

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: My sovereign liege, no letters, and few words,
But such as I (without your special pardon)
Dare not relate.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Go to, we pardon thee; therefore, in brief,
Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them.
What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: At my depart, these were his very words:
“Go tell false Edward, the supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride.”

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Is Lewis so brave? Belike he thinks me Henry.
But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: These were her words, utt’red with mild disdain:
“Tell him, in hope he’ll prove a widower shortly,
I’ll wear the willow garland for his sake.”

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: I blame not her: she could say little less;
She had the wrong. But what said Henry’s queen?
For I have heard that she was there in place.

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: “Tell him,” quoth she, “my mourning weeds are done,
And I am ready to put armor on.”

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Belike she minds to play the Amazon.
But what said Warwick to these injuries?

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: He, more incens’d against your Majesty
Than all the rest, discharg’d me with these words:
“Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I’ll uncrown him ere’t be long.”

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Ha? Durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?
Well, I will arm me, being thus forewarn’d.
They shall have wars, and pay for their presumption.
But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

speech.speaker: POST.
speech.line: Ay, gracious sovereign, they are so link’d in friendship
That young Prince Edward marries Warwick’s daughter.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.
Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast,
For I will hence to Warwick’s other daughter,
That though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage
I may not prove inferior to yourself.
You that love me and Warwick, follow me.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Not I;
My thoughts aim at a further matter: I
Stay not for the love of Edward, but the crown.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick?
Yet am I arm’d against the worst can happen;
And haste is needful in this desp’rate case.
Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf
Go levy men, and make prepare for war;
They are already or quickly will be landed.
Myself in person will straight follow you.
But ere I go, Hastings and Montague,
Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest,
Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance:
Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?
If it be so, then both depart to him;
I rather wish you foes than hollow friends.
But if you mind to hold your true obedience,
Give me assurance with some friendly vow,
That I may never have you in suspect.

speech.speaker: MONT.
speech.line: So God help Montague as he proves true!

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: And Hastings as he favors Edward’s cause!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Why, so! Then am I sure of victory.
Now therefore let us hence, and lose no hour,
Till we meet Warwick with his foreign pow’r.

scene.scenelocation: A plain in Warwickshire.
scene.scenepersonae: (Warwick, Oxford, French Soldiers, Clarence, Somerset)
scene.scenedescription: Warwick notes how the common people are on their side, and welcomes Clarence and Somerset. He promises his daughter’s hand to Clarence, and plans a surprise attack to capture Edward.
scene.stagedir: Enter Warwick and Oxford in England, with French Soldiers.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well,
The common people by numbers swarm to us.
But see where Somerset and Clarence comes!
Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Fear not that, my lord.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick,
And welcome, Somerset! I hold it cowardice
To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
Hath pawn’d an open hand in sign of love;
Else might I think that Clarence, Edward’s brother,
Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings.
But welcome, sweet Clarence, my daughter shall be thine.
And now what rests but, in night’s coverture,
Thy brother being carelessly encamp’d,
His soldiers lurking in the town about,
And but attended by a simple guard,
We may surprise and take him at our pleasure?
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy;
That as Ulysses and stout Diomede
With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus’ tents
And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds,
So we, well cover’d with the night’s black mantle,
At unawares may beat down Edward’s guard,
And seize himself; I say not, slaughter him,
For I intend but only to surprise him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.
Why then, let’s on our way in silent sort.
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!

scene.scenelocation: Edward’s camp near Warwick.
scene.scenepersonae: (Three Watchmen, Warwick, Clarence, Oxford, Somerset, French Soldiers, King Edward, Richard of Gloucester, Hastings)
scene.scenedescription: Three watchmen guard Edward’s tent, commenting on the King’s decision not to sleep in a proper bed until Warwick is dealt with, and his foolishness in sleeping far away from the bulk of his men. Warwick and his companions attack and capture Edward, Richard and Hastings managing to flee. Warwick de-crowns Edward, announcing that he is no longer anything but Duke of York, and sends him to the Archbishop of York (Warwick’s brother) for safekeeping. He then marches for London, meaning to free Henry from the Tower.
scene.stagedir: Enter three Watchmen to guard the King’s tent.

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand,
The King by this is set him down to sleep.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: What, will he not to bed?

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow
Never to lie and take his natural rest
Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress’d.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Tomorrow then belike shall be the day,
If Warwick be so near as men report.

speech.speaker: 3. WATCH.
speech.line: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that
That with the King here resteth in his tent?

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: ’Tis the Lord Hastings, the King’s chiefest friend.

speech.speaker: 3. WATCH.
speech.line: O, is it so? But why commands the King
That his chief followers lodge in towns about him,
While he himself keeps in the cold field?

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: ’Tis the more honor, because more dangerous.

speech.speaker: 3. WATCH.
speech.line: Ay, but give me worship and quietness,
I like it better than a dangerous honor.
If Warwick knew in what estate he stands,
’Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Ay; wherefore else guard we his royal tent
But to defend his person from night-foes?

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwick, Clarence, Oxford, Somerset, and French Soldiers, silent all.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: This is his tent, and see where stand his guard.
Courage, my masters! Honor now or never!
But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Who goes there?

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Stay, or thou diest!

scene.stagedir: Warwick and the rest cry all, “Warwick! Warwick!” and set upon the Guard, who fly, crying, “Arm! Arm!” , Warwick and the rest following them.
The Drum playing and Trumpet sounding, enter Warwick, Somerset, and the rest, bringing the King Edward out in his gown, sitting in a chair. Richard of Gloucester and Hastings fly over the stage.

speech.speaker: D. SOM.
speech.line: What are they that fly there?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Richard and Hastings. Let them go, here is The Duke.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: The Duke? Why, Warwick, when we parted,
Thou call’dst me King.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Ay, but the case is alter’d.
When you disgrac’d me in my embassade,
Then I degraded you from being king,
And come now to create you Duke of York.
Alas, how should you govern any kingdom,
That know not how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to be contented with one wife,
Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,
Nor how to study for the people’s welfare,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Yea, brother of Clarence, art thou here too?
Nay then I see that Edward needs must down.
Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance,
Of thee thyself and all thy complices,
Edward will always bear himself as king.
Though Fortune’s malice overthrow my state,
My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Then for his mind, be Edward England’s king.
But Henry now shall wear the English crown,
And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey’d
Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.
When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows,
I’ll follow you, and tell what answer
Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him.
Now for awhile farewell, good Duke of York.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: What fates impose, that men must needs abide;
It boots not to resist both wind and tide.

speech.speaker: OXF.
speech.line: What now remains, my lords, for us to do
But march to London with our soldiers?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Ay, that’s the first thing that we have to do,
To free King Henry from imprisonment,
And see him seated in the regal throne.

scene.scenelocation: London. A palace room.
scene.scenepersonae: (Rivers, Queen Elizabeth)
scene.scenedescription: Queen Elizabeth (the former lady Grey) tells her brother Rivers that all is lost for the Yorkist cause, and that she is going to take sanctuary to save Edward’s unborn heir.
scene.stagedir: Enter Rivers and Lady Grey, now Queen Elizabeth.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Why, brother Rivers, are you yet to learn
What late misfortune is befall’n King Edward?

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: What? Loss of some pitch’d battle against Warwick?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Then is my sovereign slain?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner,
Either betray’d by falsehood of his guard
Or by his foe surpris’d at unawares;
And as I further have to understand,
Is new committed to the Bishop of York,
Fell Warwick’s brother, and by that our foe.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: These news I must confess are full of grief,
Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:
Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Till then fair hope must hinder live’s decay;
And I the rather wain me from despair
For love of Edward’s offspring in my womb.
This is it that makes me bridle passion,
And bear with mildness my misfortune’s cross;
Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear,
And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs,
Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown
King Edward’s fruit, true heir to th’ English crown.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: I am inform’d that he comes towards London
To set the crown once more on Henry’s head.
Guess thou the rest; King Edward’s friends must down.
But to prevent the tyrant’s violence
(For trust not him that hath once broken faith),
I’ll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary,
To save, at least, the heir of Edward’s right;
There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.
Come therefore, let us fly while we may fly,
If Warwick take us we are sure to die.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. A park near Middleham Castle.
scene.scenepersonae: (Richard of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, Sir William Stanley, King Edward, Huntsman)
scene.scenedescription: By arrangement, Gloucester, Hastings, and Stanley meet Edward as he hunts in captivity. he flees with them to Flanders, where they plan to get help to regain his throne.
scene.stagedir: Enter Richard of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and Sir William Stanley.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley,
Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither
Into this chiefest thicket of the park.
Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother,
Is prisoner to the Bishop here, at whose hands
He hath good usage and great liberty,
And often but attended with weak guard,
Comes hunting this way to disport himself.
I have advertis’d him by secret means
That if about this hour he make this way,
Under the color of his usual game,
He shall here find his friends with horse and men
To set him free from his captivity.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Edward, and a Huntsman with him.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: This way, my lord, for this way lies the game.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Nay, this way, man, see where the huntsmen stand.
Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Stand you thus close to steal the Bishop’s deer?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Brother, the time and case requireth haste,
Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: But whither shall we then?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: To Lynn, my lord—
And shipp’d from thence to Flanders?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Well guess’d, believe me, for that was my meaning.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: But wherefore stay we? ’Tis no time to talk.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Huntsman, what say’st thou? Wilt thou go along?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Better do so than tarry and be hang’d.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Come then away, let’s ha’ no more ado.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Bishop, farewell! Shield thee from Warwick’s frown,
And pray that I may repossess the crown.

scene.scenelocation: London. The Tower.
scene.scenepersonae: (King Henry the Sixth, Clarence, Warwick, Somerset, Henry Richmond, Oxford, Montague, Lieutenant of the Tower, Warwick’s Messenger)
scene.scenedescription: Henry is released from prison by Warwick, but has no great interest in ruling. Rather, he makes Warwick and Clarence joint Protectors of the realm. The two men make plans to seize all of Edward’s lands and pronounce him a traitor. Henry asks that his Queen and his son be brought over from France. The King sees the young Earl of Richmond by Somerset’s side, and predicts that he is the future hope of England. News is brought of Edward,s escape, which causes great worry. Somerset and oxford agree to send Richmond to Brittany for safety in the approaching strife.
scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King Henry the Sixth, Clarence, Warwick, Somerset, young Henry Richmond, Oxford, Montague, and Lieutenant of the Tower.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Master Lieutenant, now that God and friends
Have shaken Edward from the regal seat,
And turn’d my captive state to liberty,
My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys,
At our enlargement what are thy due fees?

speech.speaker: LIEU.
speech.line: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sov’reigns,
But if an humble prayer may prevail,
I then crave pardon of your Majesty.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: For what, Lieutenant? For well using me?
Nay, be thou sure, I’ll well requite thy kindness,
For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;
Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds
Conceive, when, after many moody thoughts,
At last by notes of household harmony
They quite forget their loss of liberty.
But, Warwick, after God, thou set’st me free,
And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee.
He was the author, thou the instrument.
Therefore that I may conquer fortune’s spite
By living low, where fortune cannot hurt me,
And that the people of this blessed land
May not be punish’d with my thwarting stars,
Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,
I here resign my government to thee,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Your Grace hath still been fam’d for virtuous,
And now may seem as wise as virtuous
By spying and avoiding fortune’s malice,
For few men rightly temper with the stars;
Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace,
For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway,
To whom the heav’ns in thy nativity
Adjudg’d an olive branch and laurel crown,
As likely to be blest in peace and war;
And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: And I choose Clarence only for Protector.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Warwick and Clarence, give me both your hands.
Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,
That no dissension hinder government.
I make you both Protectors of this land,
While I myself will lead a private life,
And in devotion spend my latter days,
To sin’s rebuke and my Creator’s praise.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: What answers Clarence to his sovereign’s will?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
